main.name: Dev Niyogi
main.occupation: Professor and William Stamps Farish Chair, Department of Geological(Earth and Planetary) Sciences, Jackson School of Geosciences, and Department of Civil, Architectural and Environmental Engineering, Cockrell School of Engineering, Affiliate Faculty: Oden Institute for Computational Engineering and Sciences, and UT Center for Space Research, The University of Texas at Austin
main.description: Here will be your description. Use this to describe what you do or whatever you feel best describes yourself to a potential employer
main.bio: Use this bio section as your way of describing yourself and saying what you do, what technologies you like to use or feel most comfortable with, describing your personality, or whatever else you feel like throwing in.
main.contactmessage: Here is where you should write your message to readers to have them get in contact with you.

resume.skillmessage: Here you can create a short write-up of your skills to show off to employers

publications.content: Patel,P., Kalyanam, R., He, L., Aliaga, D., & Niyogi, D., 2023: Deep Learning based Urban Morphology for City-scale Environmental Modeling, Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences (PNAS) Nexus, https://doi.org/10.1093/pnasnexus/pgad027

Mohanty, S., Swain, M., Nadimpalli, R., Osuri, K. K., Mohanty, U. C., Patel, P., & Niyogi, D., 2023: Meteorological Conditions of Extreme Heavy Rains over Coastal City Mumbai, Journal of Applied Meteorology and Climatology, 62(2), 191-208.

Cammarano, D., Jamshidi, S., Hoogenboom, G., Ruane, A.C., Niyogi, D. & Ronga, D., 2023: Processing tomato production is expected to decrease by 2050 due to the projected increase in temperature. Nature Food, 3(6), pp.437-444.

Busireddy, N.K.R., Ankur, K., Osuri, K.K. & Niyogi, D., 2022: Modelled impact of ocean warming on tropical cyclone size and destructiveness over the Bay of Bengal: A case study on FANI cyclone. Atmospheric Research, 279, p.106355.

Cao, J., Wang, H., Li, J., Tian, Q., & Niyogi, D., 2022: Improving the Forecasting of Winter Wheat Yields in Northern China with Machine Learning–Dynamical Hybrid Subseasonal-to-Seasonal Ensemble Prediction. Remote Sensing. 14, 1707.
Sui, X., Li, Z., Tang, G., Yang, Z.L. & Niyogi, D., 2022: Disentangling error structures of precipitation datasets using decision trees. Remote Sensing of Environment, 280, p.113185.

Mills, G., Stewart, I.D. & Niyogi, D., 2022: The origins of modern urban climate science: reflections on 'A numerical model of the urban heat island'. Progress in Physical Geography: Earth and Environment, 46, 649-656.

Zhang, X., Huang, T., Gulakhmadov, A., Song, Y., Gu, X., Zeng, J., Huang, S., Nam, W.H., Chen, N. & Niyogi, D., 2022: Deep Learning-Based 500 m Spatio-Temporally Continuous Air Temperature Generation by Fusing Multi-Source Data. Remote Sensing, 14, 3536.

Patel, P., Jamshidi, S., Nadimpalli, R., Aliaga, D.G., Mills, G., Chen, F., Demuzere, M. & Niyogi, D., 2022: Modeling Large‐Scale Heatwave by Incorporating Enhanced Urban Representation. Journal of Geophysical Research: Atmospheres, 127(2), p.e2021JD035316.

Tyagi, S., Zhang, X., Saraswat, D., Sahany, S., Mishra, S.K. & Niyogi, D., 2022. Flash Drought: Review of Concept, Prediction and the Potential for Machine Learning, Deep Learning Methods. Earth's Future, 10(11), p.e2022EF002723.

Kaginalkar, A., Kumar, S., Gargava, P. & Niyogi, D., 2021: Review of urban computing in air quality management as smart city service: An integrated IoT, AI, and cloud technology perspective. Urban Climate, 39, p.100972.

Terfa, B.K., Chen, N., Zhang, X. & Niyogi, D., 2020: Spatial configuration and extent explains the urban heat mitigation potential due to green spaces: Analysis over Addis Ababa, Ethiopia. Remote Sensing, 12, 2876.
Liu, J. & Niyogi, D., 2020: Identification of linkages between urban heat Island magnitude and urban rainfall modification by use of causal discovery algorithms. Urban Climate, 33, p.100659.

Ching, J., & coauthors including D. Niyogi, 2019: Pathway using WUDAPT's Digital Synthetic City tool towards generating urban canopy parameters for multi-scale urban atmospheric modeling. Urban Climate, 28, 100459.

work.company: The University of Texas at Austin
work.title: Professor, Endowed Professor and then Chair Professor, Department of Geological (Earth and Planetary) Sciences, and Department of Civil, Architectural and Environmental Engineering
Affiliated Faculty, Oden Institute of Computational Science and Engineering, University of Texas, Center for Space Research, and UT Environmental Science Institute
Professor, Department of Agronomy, and Department of Earth, Atmospheric and Planetary Sciences
Assistant and then Associate Professor with Tenure

skills.name: Elected Board Member, International Association of Urban Climatology (IAUC), 2018- 2024
Member, U.S. Department of Energy, Biological and Environmental Research Advisory Committee (2022-)
Invited Committee Member of the American Meteorological Society- Board on Urban Environment (BUE; Chair from 2014-2019); Committee on Applied Climatology (2020- 2022)
Editor AMS Journal of Applied Meteorology and Climatology (JAMC), and Topic Editor Computational Urban Science
Theme Organizing Committee Member of the UT Austin Bridging Barrier Planet Texas 2050
Honorary Member, Council for Scientific Society Presidents (CSSP), 2021-.
Helmut E. Landsberg Award for Urban Climate from American Meteorological Society, 2023
William Stamps Farish Chair (2022-onwards); John “Brick” Elliott Endowed Professor (2020-22); David Carleton Professor (2020), at UT Austin
Number of media interviews and media highlights including on PBS Newshour, NPR, CBS, Fox News, Wired Magazine, National Geographic, and international outlets
Indiana Governor’s Team Award for Environmental Excellence (2018)
TedX Talk on Eroding Differences and Similarities
Purdue ‘Seeds for Success’ award – recognizing “Million Dollar Researchers” (2009)
Outstanding Service plaque for 1st Agricultural Air Quality workshop – Presented by CSREES administrator at the first workshop on agricultural air quality, Maryland, June 8, 2006.

testimonials.text: Here you should write some nice things that someone has said about you. No lies though, employers can tell when you are lying.

That Tim Baker must be one of the most brilliant developers I've ever met! It is amazing that nobody has hired him yet. Hey you, you should hire this guy, he may be fresh out of University and have zero on the job experience but I am confident that he will be one of your best developers in no time!
